After receiving the ten precepts of a Å›rÄmaá¹‡era, one becomes a virtuous practitioner. Next, one is taught the proper conduct, gradually
accumulating from a young age.
One should know the rules of conduct;
One should know the age of the preceptor and the names of the three teachers;
One should be taught to recognize the year, month, and day of first receiving the precepts;

One should know the number of duties in serving the preceptor, and also know the number of duties in following the ÄcÄrya, and also know the number of duties in offering willow branches and washing water, and also know the number of duties in bestowing the kÄá¹£Äya robe and holding the alms bowl, and also know the number of duties in holding the tin staff and carrying shoes.

When invited together with the preceptor and ÄcÄrya, when arriving at the king's house, when arriving at the Ká¹£atriya's house, when arriving at the Brahmin's house, when eating while sitting together, when eating while sitting separately;
If they enter the city together to beg for food, or if they return together to the original place;
If they eat by the water's edge in the late afternoon, or if they eat together under a tree;
If one goes first and waits for the other;
If they eat from combined bowls or exchange bowls;
If they eat facing each other or before and after each other;
If they rinse after eating or wash the bowls and leave.
If they are fully aware of the time to provide for the Sangha, they should know how many things there are.
When they are twenty years old and wish to receive the precepts, they should be fully aware of them.
If a wise one does not fully understand the questions asked by the bhiká¹£us, he should not be given the full precepts.
Why is this?
As a novice, he does not know the practices of a novice.
The affairs of a Å›ramaá¹‡a are very difficult to do and extremely subtle.
Wise novice!
You should go and study thoroughly, hear and understand everything, and then you may receive the full precepts.
The reason you do not know all the duties of a novice monk is because you have come together and know well, because of your good body;
You do not know because you have not subdued your mind.

Yet you want to return to receive full ordination. Now, if I give you full ordination, people will say that the Buddha's teachings are easy to practice and that becoming a monk is easy, not knowing that the Buddha's path is profound and that the workings of blessings and sins alternate according to the law.
For this reason, I should first ask you.
If the master can answer completely and in accordance with the Dharma, then the three teachers will be easily found.
The teacher teaches the novice monk with five things:
First, you should respect senior monks;
Second, you should not address senior monks by name;
Third, when senior monks are reciting the precepts, you should not eavesdrop;
Fourth, you should not seek out the faults of senior monks;
Fifth, if a senior monk makes a mistake, you should not spread it around.
These are the rules of deportment.
You should be taught to practice five things:
First, one should not scold a great bhiká¹£u in a secluded place.
Second, one should not belittle a great bhiká¹£u, teasing or imitating their speech, appearance, or gait in front of them.
Third, when seeing a great bhiká¹£u passing by, one should stand up if reading sÅ«tras;
if eating or doing various tasks, one need not stand up.
Fourth, when walking and encountering a great bhiká¹£u, one should stop and step aside on the lower path.
Fifth, if teasing or seeing a great bhiká¹£u, one should immediately stop and apologize, saying it was not appropriate.
This is how one should conduct oneself.
There are ten things for a Å›rÄmaá¹‡era to attend to his preceptor:
First, one should rise early;
Second, when entering the room, one should first snap one's fingers three times;
Third, prepare toothpicks and water for washing;
Fourth, offer one's kÄá¹£Äya robe and then one's sandals;
Fifth, sweep the floor and refill the washing water;
Sixth, wipe the bed and seat clean;
Seventh, when the teacher has gone out and has not yet returned, one should not leave the room in the middle. When the teacher returns, one should take the outer robe and fold it back.
Eighth, if there are offenses, the preceptor or teacher should admonish one, and one should not speak back.
Ninth, one should lower one's head, receive the teacher's words, and contemplate and practice them.
Tenth, when going out, one should pull the door closed.
These are the rules for serving the preceptor.
There are five things for a novice to serve the teacher:
First, one should view the teacher as if viewing me.
Second, one should not be frivolous.
Third, if scolded, one should not speak back.
Fourth, if asked to empty a dirty vessel, one should not spit or be angry.
Fifth, when staying overnight, one should massage the teacher.
These are the rules for serving the teacher.
There are six things for a novice to serve the teacher by getting up early and preparing toothpicks and water:
First, when breaking off a toothpick, one should follow the proper length;
Second, you should break the head of the toothbrush;
Third, you should wash it to make it clean;
Fourth, you should change the old water;
Fifth, you should clean the water container;
Sixth, you should fill it with water and bring it in without making a sound.
This is the method for providing toothbrushes and water for washing.
There are four things to do when handing over the kÄá¹£Äya robe:
First, you should slowly hold it with one hand and hand it over;
Second, you should look at the top and bottom in order;
Third, you should hold the teacher's robe and stand properly;
Fourth, you should put it on your shoulders.
This is the method for the kÄá¹£Äya robe.
There are four things to do when folding the kÄá¹£Äya robe:
First, you should look at the top and bottom;
Second, you should not let it touch the ground;
Third, you should put it in its usual place;
Fourth, cover it on top.
This is the method for folding the kÄá¹£Äya robe.
There are four things to do when holding the alms bowl:ğŸ”½First, you should wash it to make it clean;
Second, you should wipe it dry;
Third, you should fasten the strap;
Fourth, you should not make a sound.
This is the method for holding the alms bowl.
There are four things to keep in mind when carrying shoes:
First, shake them off first;
Second, look at them and put them in order;
Third, wash your hands and do not hold the kasaya immediately;
Fourth, when the teacher sits, take them and put them in order.
This is the method for carrying shoes.
There are four things to keep in mind when carrying a staff:
First, wipe off the dirt;
Second, do not put it on the ground to make a sound;
Third, hand it to the teacher when he goes out;
Fourth, when the teacher comes out, take it back. If walking together, entering the assembly, or paying homage to the Buddha, take it and hold it.
This is the method for carrying a staff.
There are four things to keep in mind when invited to sit together for a meal:
First, if sitting, one should be six feet away from the teacher;
Second, look at the teacher's great offering and then offer the bowl;
Third, do not eat before the teacher;
Fourth, after eating, stand up and take the bowl close to oneself.
This is the rule for eating while sitting together.
The rule for eating while sitting separately has four parts:
First, one should stand by the teacher's side;
Second, when instructed to eat, one should sit down;
Third, one should bow with one's head to the ground;
Fourth, after eating, one should not sit arrogantly or play.
After eating, one should return to the teacher's side and stand there. When instructed by the teacher to sit, one should then sit down.
This is the rule for eating while sitting separately.
When entering the city to beg for food, there are four things:
First, one should carry the teacher's alms bowl;
Second, one should follow behind, not allowing one's feet to step on the teacher's shadow;
Third, outside the city, one should take the bowl and offer it to the teacher;
Fourth, when entering the city and wanting to go separately, one should inform the teacher.
This is the rule for going to beg for food.
When returning together to the original place to eat, there are four things:
First, one should slowly open the door, come out, and spread out the sitting mat;
Second, after washing the teacher's hands, one should then wash one's own;
Third, the disciple should receive the teacher's bowl and stand with hands clasped;
Fourth, the disciple should prepare bean soup and a towel in advance.
These are the rules for returning to the meal.
There are four rules for eating by the water's edge:
First, one should seek a clean place;
Second, one should seek grass to make a seat;
Third, one should take water to wash the teacher's hands and then offer the bowl;
Fourth, when the teacher instructs one to eat, one should bow and then sit.
These are the rules for eating by the water's edge.
There are four rules for eating under a tree:
First, one should place the bowl on a tree branch and take leaves to make a seat;
Second, one should take water to wash the teacher's hands, and if one cannot obtain water, one should seek clean grass to offer to the teacher;
Third, one should take back the teacher's bowl and offer it to the teacher;
Fourth, one should prepare clean grass in advance, and after washing the teacher's bowl, wipe it thoroughly before leaving.
These are the rules for eating under a tree.
There are three rules for waiting while staying on the road:
First, hold the alms bowl on a clean place and bow as instructed;
Second, look at the time, whether it is early or late, and decide whether to return or continue on the road;
Third, take the teacher's bowl and hold it behind you.
This is the method of waiting for each other on the road.
There are three things to do when eating together in the bowl:
First, if there is no curd, ghee, or juice in the teacher's bowl, take your own bowl and offer it to the teacher;
If the teacher does not accept it, then stand aside.
Second, slowly take half of the rice from the bowl and place it on a leaf.
Third, take half of the rice from your own bowl and place it in the teacher's bowl, then stand aside.
This is the method of eating together in the bowl.
There are three things to do when exchanging bowls:
First, if the teacher's bowl contains good food while your own is not as good, then offer it to the teacher;
Second, if the teacher wants to exchange bowls, politely decline;
Third, if the teacher insists on exchanging bowls, take one more bite, wipe the bowl, and return it to the teacher.
This is the rule for trading bowls.
There are three things when facing food:
First, you should offer the bowl to the teacher and then eat yourself;
Second, you should frequently look at the teacher to see what he wants, and then get up to get it for him;
Third, you should not eat too quickly or too slowly. After getting up, you should ask again what he wants.
If the teacher says to take it away, then you should take it away.
This is the rule for facing food.
There are three things when eating before or after the teacher:
First, after taking the teacher's bowl and utensils, you should go to a secluded place and stand there. When you hear the teacher calling, you should respond immediately;
Second, you should take the washing water and place it to one side in advance;
Third, after the teacher has finished eating, you should wash the teacher's hands and then stand back. When the teacher tells you to leave, you should then bow and leave.
This is the rule for eating before or after the teacher.
There are three things when rinsing after eating:
First, after rinsing, you should first take the teacher's bowl and wash it until it is clean, and then place it on a leaf;
Second, after washing one's own bowl, also place it on a tree leaf. First, take the teacher's bowl and rub it to dry, then place it in a bag and give it to the teacher;
Third, take one's own bowl back, wipe it dry, place it in a bag, and carry it back to the dwelling place.
This is the method for washing the bowl.
When leaving after washing the bowl, there are three things:
First, say I now wish to pass by the venerable so-and-so;
Second, touch one's head to the ground to pay respects and then leave;
Third, return alone.
Do not pass through other villages to play and laugh;
Go straight back to the original place to read the sutras.
This is the method for leaving after washing the bowl.
There are five things for a novice to enter the assembly:
First, one should study diligently;
Second, one should practice various matters;
Third, one should serve the assembly;
Fourth, one should provide things for the fully ordained monks;
Fifth, when wishing to receive full ordination, it is easy to obtain the three teachers.
There are also five things:
First, one should pay respects to the Buddha;
Second, you should bow to the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha;ğŸ”½Third, you should greet the senior monk;
Fourth, you should leave the seat for the senior monk;
Fifth, you should not dispute over seating places.
There are also five things:
First, you should not call out to each other and laugh while sitting;
Second, you should not get up and leave frequently;
Third, if the saá¹…gha calls out, Novice monk so-and-so, you should immediately get up and respond;
Fourth, you should follow the instructions of the saá¹…gha;
Fifth, if the monastery manager calls you to do something, you should return and inform your teacher.
This is the method for entering the assembly.
When a novice monk is on duty, there are five things:
First, you should be frugal with the saá¹…gha's belongings;
Second, you should not do things in the middle of the road;
Third, if the work is not yet finished, you should not get up and leave in the middle;
Fourth, if your preceptor or teacher calls you, you should not go immediately, but should inform the monastery manager;
Fifth, you should follow the instructions of the monastery manager and not disobey.
This is the method for selecting the day of work.
There are five things to consider when selecting vegetables:
First, cut off the roots;
Second, cut them to the same length;
Third, do not mix the green and yellow ones;
Fourth, when washing the vegetables, change the water three times to make them clean, then shake them three times to remove the water;
Fifth, after finishing the work, sweep and clean the area.
There are five more things:
First, do not take the Sangha's things privately;
Second, if you want to take something, report it to the karmadÄna;
Third, do your best to do the Sangha's work;ğŸ”½Fourth, sweep the dining hall and put away the empty tables;
Fifth, sweep the area behind the toilets and replenish the water in the morning and evening.
There are ten things to consider when drawing water:
First, if your hands are dirty, do not use them to draw water. You should wash your hands first;
Second, do not throw the bucket into the well with a loud noise;
Third, when lowering the bucket, do so slowly and gently, do not make a loud noise by shaking it around to the left and right.
Fourth, do not allow the rope to fall back into the well.
Fifth, do not place your shoes on the well railing.
Sixth, do not pour the water from the bucket directly into the cauldron.
Seventh, do not place the bucket on the ground.
Eighth, wash the water container until it is clean.
Ninth, when carrying water, do so carefully.
Tenth, place it in a hidden place, do not obstruct people's paths.
There are five things to do when washing the cauldron:ğŸ”½First, wash the rim of the cauldron first;
Second, wash the inside of the cauldron;
Third, wash the middle, waist, and belly;
Fourth, wash the inside and bottom;
Fifth, change the water three times.
There are five things to do when blowing on the stove:
First, do not squat and blow on the fire;
Second, do not burn raw firewood;ğŸ”½Third, do not blow upside down on wet firewood;
Fourth, do not burn rotten firewood;
Fifth, do not extinguish the fire with boiling water.
There are five things when sweeping the ground:
First, sweep in a straight line;
Second, when sprinkling the ground, do not make it too thick or too thin;
Third, do not splash the four walls;
Fourth, do not step on the wet ground and damage it;
Fifth, after sweeping, immediately pick up the grass and discard it.
When the bhiká¹£u monks are eating, the Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras sweep the ground. There are five things:
First, sweep backwards;
Second, do not swing your arms;
Third, pass by six people and make one pile;
Fourth, it is good to sweep all around;
Fifth, immediately pick it up with your own hands and discard it.
There are five things when holding a water basin and pouring water:
First, hold the top with one hand and the bottom with the other, do not switch hands.
Second, hold it close to the left side and firmly look straight ahead.
Third, look at the person's hand when pouring down the water, do not use too much or too little, just pour it into the person's hand.
Fourth, when washing the hands, they should be four inches below the water, neither too high nor too low, and they should look at each other to see how much water there is;
If there is little water and it is not enough for one person, they should add more, and they should not keep their hands in the water.
Fifth, after washing the hands, they should put on the kaá¹£Äya robe again.
There are five things to keep in mind when holding the washing bowl:
First, one should not make a sound with the bowl;
Second, one should hold it firmly with both hands and lean it against the right side of the face;
Third, one should follow the height of the other person's hands, and should not look around to the left and right;
Fourth, when the washing bowl is full, one should pour it out and discard it, and should not splash water on the ground in front of others;
Fifth, after washing, one should pass the bowl, wash one's hands again, and put on the kaá¹£Äya robe.
There are five things to keep in mind when using a hand towel:
First, one should hold the upper end with the right hand and the lower end with the left hand, and hand it to the other person with one end;
Second, one should sit two feet away, and should not lean forward on the other person's lap;
Third, one should hold the towel and should not cover one's mouth while talking;
Fourth, if the towel has not been put down by the person wiping, one should not pull it away. After finishing, one should inform the master or put it back in its original place;
Fifth, one should then wash one's hands and put on the kÄá¹£Äya robe again.
There are five things to do when handing over the sandals:
First, one should shake them out to remove any contents inside;
Second, one should start from the upper seat;
Third, one should show them to the master so that they can recognize them themselves;
Fourth, one should not put the left one on the right, but should put them down after finishing;
Fifth, after finishing, one should wash one's hands and put on the kÄá¹£Äya robe again.
There are seven things for a novice monk's alms bowl:
First, if there is leftover rice in the bowl, one should not take it and discard it;
Second, if one wants to discard rice, one should put it on a clean place;
Third, one should use jujube beans or grass leaves;
Fourth, one should not wash the bowl on a clean place or in the middle of the road;
Fifth, one should make sure there is a support underneath the bowl;
Sixth, one should add clean water, and not discard the water far away, splashing on people or the ground;
Seventh, when wanting to pour out the water in the bowl, one should be four inches away from the ground, neither too high nor too low.
There are three things to wipe the bowl:
First, one should wash one's hands and wipe them dry;
Second, one should hold a clean towel and place it on one's lap;
Third, one should wipe the inside and make it dry, then immediately cover it with a clean towel and place it in a bag in its usual place.
When going to a gathering meal, there are five things to teach the novice to hold the bowl:
First, one should not place it on the ground;
Second, one should not stack it making a sound;
Third, ask to place it on the ground;
Fourth, if the person has not yet received the bowl, one should not hold the bowl and place it on the table;
Fifth, one should not follow behind the person giving the bowl, but should follow in front, and also not in the crowd.
When seeing that the teacher has finished eating, one should rise, take the bowl, and return to one's seat.
There are seven things for a novice to carry a letter for the teacher to someone to express gratitude:
First, one should go straight;
Second, one should return straight;
Third, one should know what the teacher says and also know how to respond to others;
Fourth, one should not pass by without reason;
Fifth, if one borrows something, one should not stay overnight;
Sixth, one should not be frivolous;
Seventh, one should have rules when going out.
A novice monk should not enter the room of a fully ordained monk without reason while he is still serving the Sangha.
There are three circumstances under which he may enter:
First, if he is temporarily sent by his preceptor or teacher;
Second, if he is asked to take something;
Third, if he goes to ask about the sutras, he may enter.
There are seven things to do when entering a room:
First, one should snap one's fingers three times before entering;
Second, one should not stand in the way;
Third, one should not speak about others' affairs without reason;
Fourth, one should join one's palms and speak according to the Dharma;
Fifth, one should not sit with one's legs crossed;
Sixth, one should not be frivolous;
Seventh, one should not block others from leaving first. If one wishes to leave, one should return to pull the door.
When sending a novice monk on a long journey alone, one should teach him three things:
First, if others ask you, What is your preceptor's name? you should reply, My preceptor's name is so-and-so.
Second, they may ask again, How many years has your preceptor been a monk? you should reply, He has been a monk for so many years.
Third, they may ask again, Where is your preceptor from? you should reply, He is from such-and-such a prefecture.
If they ask again, What is your preceptor's name? you should reply, His name is so-and-so.
They may ask again, How old is your preceptor? you should reply, He is so many years old.ğŸ”½They may ask again, Where is your preceptor from? you should reply, He is from such-and-such a prefecture.
If they ask again, Where are you from, Venerable? you should reply, I am from such-and-such a prefecture.
They may ask again, What is your name, Venerable? you should reply, My name is so-and-so.
He asked again, How many years have you been a novice monk? The novice monk replied, For so many years, so many months and days, and so many hours.
This is knowing the preceptor and master, and also knowing the time, name, year, month, and day oneself.
There are five things to do when entering the bathhouse:
First, lower your head when entering;
Second, avoid the seat of the senior monk;
Third, do not speak recklessly when the senior monk is reading the sutra;
Fourth, do not wash each other with water;
Fifth, do not pour water to extinguish the fire.
There are also five things:
First, do not be frivolous;
Second, do not break the basin or jar;
Third, do not waste too much water;
Fourth, do not muddy the bath beans or sesame oil;
Fifth, do not stop washing clothes after leaving.
There are ten things to do when going to the back of the house:
First, if you want to defecate or urinate, you should go immediately;
Second, do not look around when going;
Third, when arriving, one should snap one's fingers three times;
Fourth, one should not rush the person in the middle to leave;
Fifth, having arrived, one should snap one's fingers three times again;
Sixth, one should not swallow loudly;
Seventh, one should not lower one's head to look at one's lap;
Eighth, one should not play with the ashes on top;
Ninth, one should not sprinkle water on the walls;
Tenth, having finished, one should wash one's hands. If they are not washed, one should not hold anything.
There are also five things:
First, one should not spit directly at the front wall;
Second, one should not look around to the left and right;
Third, one should not draw on the ground with grass;
Fourth, one should not draw on the ground or walls with a burning stick;
Fifth, one should not stay for too long. Having finished, one should quickly leave.
If one encounters people, one should not bow to them, but step off the path to avoid them.
The ten rules for novice monks;
First, all sentient beings depend on food and drink to survive;
Second, the two truths;
Third, the three feelings;
Fourth, the four noble truths;
Fifth, the five aggregates;
Sixth, the six sense bases;
Seventh, the seven factors of awakening;
Eighth, the eightfold noble path;
Ninth, the nine abodes of sentient beings;
Tenth, the ten universal bases.
These are called the ten categories.
Novices:
First, giving rise to the aspiration to leave the mundane and embrace the Way;
Second, destroying one's attractive appearance and conforming to the Dharma robes;
Third, forever cutting off affection for one's relatives, with no attachment;
Fourth, disregarding one's body and life, and upholding the Way;
Fifth, aspiring to the Great Vehicle in order to deliver others.
Respectfully addressing the four venerable assemblies of the great saá¹…gha!
The novice so-and-so, together with so many people, bow our heads in reverence.

I have heard that when the sun's halo appears, the people are blessed with brightness. When the true and venerable one expounds the teachings, there is the thought of enlightenment. In the prosperous and harmonious assembly, the sun-like holy transformation illuminates. The vast Dharma that is followed is like the sun's halo. The monks gather in the hall to recite the precepts.
The precepts can eliminate evil and are the foundation of myriad good deeds. They are the basis for the arising of wondrous practices and liberation.
When the novice heard this, he was overjoyed and wished to make offerings, but he had no wealth or treasures.
He simply held five hundred toothpicks and one thousand pure counting rods, respectfully offering them to the pure assembly, expressing his sincere heart, removing afflictions and impurities.
I humbly request the virtuous monks to accept them with compassion and chant the blessings.
